snippet.textDisplay:
This was our last video for the year 12019 of the Human Era. And what a year it was. So much stuff happened everywhere. To so many different people.
Calendars and holidays are just imaginary but they help us to cut our lives into pieces that our brains can handle.
We are leaving 12019 behind with a weird mixture of disillusion and hope. The world is screwed up. But we can fix it. In a few days this year will be over. And we all get to try again.
Thank you for watching our videos and for sticking around for so many years. See you all in 12020.
snippet.textOriginal:
This was our last video for the year 12019 of the Human Era. And what a year it was. So much stuff happened everywhere. To so many different people.
Calendars and holidays are just imaginary but they help us to cut our lives into pieces that our brains can handle.
We are leaving 12019 behind with a weird mixture of disillusion and hope. The world is screwed up. But we can fix it. In a few days this year will be over. And we all get to try again.
Thank you for watching our videos and for sticking around for so many years. See you all in 12020.

snippet.textDisplay: As usual, a very insightful video from the channel. It's remarkable how the Astrophysicist has designed a complete stellar engine for sake of this greatly educational video. But it dawns upon me about the secondary thruster which ejects charged H-beam onto the Sun. The mass of the Sun is astronomically high for a focused H-beam to actually have it moved, since the Caplan Engine essentially taking mass out of the sun and returning some of the mass back to it while keeping the engine itself stationary. So basically, both the thruster is balancing the engine from the sheer gravitational force in the vicinity of the Sun. I don't see how there's any net external force upon the star. However, I haven't gone through the journals and articles and I hope the Astrophysicist has given more details which has not been mentioned in the video.
snippet.textOriginal: As usual, a very insightful video from the channel. It's remarkable how the Astrophysicist has designed a complete stellar engine for sake of this greatly educational video. But it dawns upon me about the secondary thruster which ejects charged H-beam onto the Sun. The mass of the Sun is astronomically high for a focused H-beam to actually have it moved, since the Caplan Engine essentially taking mass out of the sun and returning some of the mass back to it while keeping the engine itself stationary. So basically, both the thruster is balancing the engine from the sheer gravitational force in the vicinity of the Sun. I don't see how there's any net external force upon the star. However, I haven't gone through the journals and articles and I hope the Astrophysicist has given more details which has not been mentioned in the video.

snippet.textDisplay:
I think the best application of this technology would be intergalactic colonisation. Send a whole solar system, and you'd have trillions of colonists for settling a new galaxy. Ships of a few hundred thousand each at 10% of light-speed are fine for getting to solar systems a few light-years away. Getting to a new galaxy at 10% of light-speed would take tens of millions to billions of years. That sort of time-scale for a trip is best handled by a planet or solar system, which naturally lasts for billions of years.

Also, related term: Starlifting. Getting the fuel for the Caplan Thruster would be an example of it. With the plasma extracted from the sun, you could process it to separate the heavier elements for other uses before sending the hydrogen and helium to the Caplan Thruster station.
snippet.textOriginal:
I think the best application of this technology would be intergalactic colonisation. Send a whole solar system, and you'd have trillions of colonists for settling a new galaxy. Ships of a few hundred thousand each at 10% of light-speed are fine for getting to solar systems a few light-years away. Getting to a new galaxy at 10% of light-speed would take tens of millions to billions of years. That sort of time-scale for a trip is best handled by a planet or solar system, which naturally lasts for billions of years.

Also, related term: Starlifting. Getting the fuel for the Caplan Thruster would be an example of it. With the plasma extracted from the sun, you could process it to separate the heavier elements for other uses before sending the hydrogen and helium to the Caplan Thruster station.

snippet.textDisplay:
2 questions:
(1) By extracting more mass from the sun over such large periods of time, couldn't that potentially be enough to alter gravity within the solar system, as gravity is a matter of mass? (and in a worst case scenario, due to lower gravity, couldn't the solar system start falling apart? Not just starting with the outer most planet, but also affecting earth's orbit around the sun and making it uninhabitable because it drifts further away from the sun?)
(2) If the sun becomes a slower burning star, does that not correlate with a lower power density than currently? So solar power plants would produce less energy. Would that not also have an impact on the habitable zone, moving it further towards the sun and possibly leaving the earth too cold to survive for humans, unless it is moved equally further towards the sun?
snippet.textOriginal:
2 questions:
(1) By extracting more mass from the sun over such large periods of time, couldn't that potentially be enough to alter gravity within the solar system, as gravity is a matter of mass? (and in a worst case scenario, due to lower gravity, couldn't the solar system start falling apart? Not just starting with the outer most planet, but also affecting earth's orbit around the sun and making it uninhabitable because it drifts further away from the sun?)
(2) If the sun becomes a slower burning star, does that not correlate with a lower power density than currently? So solar power plants would produce less energy. Would that not also have an impact on the habitable zone, moving it further towards the sun and possibly leaving the earth too cold to survive for humans, unless it is moved equally further towards the sun?

snippet.textDisplay: That's step 1. Step 2 involves all our galactic colonies doing the same. And once they did, begin moving the entire Milky Way galaxy wherever we want it to go, so as to colonize our local group. Then, when that is done, Step 3 has us beginning to reshape the visible universe by moving sets of galaxies around. And by the time Step 4 arrives, we're already reshaping space-time to suit our ACTUAL long term best interests.
snippet.textOriginal: That's step 1. Step 2 involves all our galactic colonies doing the same. And once they did, begin moving the entire Milky Way galaxy wherever we want it to go, so as to colonize our local group. Then, when *that* is done, Step 3 has us beginning to reshape the visible universe by moving sets of galaxies around. And by the time Step 4 arrives, we're already reshaping space-time to suit our ACTUAL long term best interests.

snippet.textDisplay: How do you stop this solar system rocket?
snippet.textOriginal: How do you stop this solar system rocket?

snippet.textDisplay: Awesome video. I've always imagined star lifters being useful for manufacturing generation ships and, as Isaac Arthur and others have discussed, when you combine the idea of a star lifter with an orbital ring (the latter could also be just a Dyson Swarm, doesn't have to be solid) you could use materials extracted from the star by the stellar engine for repairing, refueling, and resupplying interstellar and even intergalactic generation ships that are very far away from the star - the orbital ring can launch all of that star lifted stuff to them. So a Kaplan thruster/stellar engine is very multifunctional: you can move the star; modifies the star's size, brightness, and expected lifetime; you can extract material from the star to use as propulsion fuel for moving the star, but you could also use that star lifted material to build immense fleets of O'Neil cylinders (slightly smaller spaceships, still big enough to hold several million people); lastly, a portion of the Dyson Swarm comprising the Kaplan thruster could also be used as a launch system (I.e. orbital ring) which could eject star lifted materials and send them along trajectories which eventually intercept interstellar/intergalactic spaceships. Heck, I bet these things have even more uses which I haven't covered; nevertheless, they have many uses. I'd love to see you guys do a video on orbital rings; that would be great.
snippet.textOriginal: Awesome video. I've always imagined star lifters being useful for manufacturing generation ships and, as Isaac Arthur and others have discussed, when you combine the idea of a star lifter with an orbital ring (the latter could also be just a Dyson Swarm, doesn't have to be solid) you could use materials extracted from the star by the stellar engine for repairing, refueling, and resupplying interstellar and even intergalactic generation ships that are very far away from the star - the orbital ring can launch all of that star lifted stuff to them. So a Kaplan thruster/stellar engine is very multifunctional: you can move the star; modifies the star's size, brightness, and expected lifetime; you can extract material from the star to use as propulsion fuel for moving the star, but you could also use that star lifted material to build immense fleets of O'Neil cylinders (slightly smaller spaceships, still big enough to hold several million people); lastly, a portion of the Dyson Swarm comprising the Kaplan thruster could also be used as a launch system (I.e. orbital ring) which could eject star lifted materials and send them along trajectories which eventually intercept interstellar/intergalactic spaceships. Heck, I bet these things have even more uses which I haven't covered; nevertheless, they have many uses. I'd love to see you guys do a video on orbital rings; that would be great.

snippet.textDisplay:
Imagine humanity in the future...
The Milky Way is almost fully colonised, almost all the solar systems have a permanent presence of humans in them, but our curiosity is endless, our pursuit of knowledge and adventure are irresistible and our greed for more resources, more than a single galaxy worth of resources are unquenchable. On that era, humans dedicated a whole solar system for extragalactic travel, the spaceship: An entire solar system, consisting of a couple of planets for metals, a couple for gases, a couple for plantation, a couple for water and a couple for major habitation. This solar-system-spaceship consisting of a range of planets for a self-sustaining supply and billions of explorers will venture outside of the Milky Way, waging through the dark expanse of space, relying on the very star propelling the system forward, to a whole new galaxy.
snippet.textOriginal:
*Imagine humanity in the future...*
The Milky Way is almost fully colonised, almost all the solar systems have a permanent presence of humans in them, but our curiosity is endless, our pursuit of knowledge and adventure are irresistible and our greed for more resources, more than a single galaxy worth of resources are unquenchable. On that era, humans dedicated a whole solar system for extragalactic travel, the spaceship: An entire solar system, consisting of a couple of planets for metals, a couple for gases, a couple for plantation, a couple for water and a couple for major habitation. This solar-system-spaceship consisting of a range of planets for a self-sustaining supply and billions of explorers will venture outside of the Milky Way, waging through the dark expanse of space, relying on the very star propelling the system forward, to a whole new galaxy.

snippet.textDisplay: After 6 Years 113 videos have been made on this channel, It's been so cool to watch your style of animation improve after every video. From the first video on your channel to the last video of 12019.  I can see how each video improves in terms of it's quality, for example how more vibrant colours are used in recent videos and how the frame rate is much smoother. Considering how long each video takes to make, a lot of time and effort has clearly been put into this channel. I've started animating as a hobby so watching your videos and observing your style has helped a lot with that and given me something to do over the holidays. If Kurzgesagt is seeing this comment then I'd just like to thank you for creating such high quality content which I get to learn from and occasionally binge if I have nothing else to do.
